clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Buddhist Monks in Providing Cognitive Behavior Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of Cognitive Behavior Therapy Provided by Buddhist Monks vs. Treatment as Usual in the Treatment of Late Life-depression

brief_summary.textblock: This research is to study the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy-CBT and Psychotherapy by trained buddhist monks. There are generally accepted that both cognitive and Buddhist concepts are related. This randomized controlled trial is to study the elderly participants who suffer major depressive disorder according to DSM-IV. The subjects will be divided into two groups. The experimental group will receive 12 sessions of CBT 2 times per week for 6 weeks in addition to usual treatment. The control group will receive treatment as usual and general conversation (non-CBT) with monks. Pretreatment factors (such as attachment style, interpersonal factors) of both therapist monks and patient participants will be studied.

primary_outcome.measure: Evidence of clinically depression confirmed by clinician
primary_outcome.time_frame: 2 months after the end of the intervention
primary_outcome.description: Depression will be assessed by HAMD-7 (McIntyre, 2005)

primary_outcome.time_frame: 2 month after the end of the inetrvention
primary_outcome.description: depression will be assessed by Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS)(Shiekh & Yesavage, 1986)

secondary_outcome.description: anxiety, depression,and somatization symptom will be assessed by the Core symptom index (CSI) (Wongpakaran, unpublished),

secondary_outcome.measure: Dimensional psychological distress ( perception of stress)
secondary_outcome.description: Perception of stress will be assessed by Perceived Stress Scale-10 (PSS-10) (Cohen 1983 ; Wongpakaran, 2010)

other_outcome.description: Working alliance will be assessed by the Helping Alliance Questionnaire (HAQ)(Luborsky, 1996)
The part includes participants' attachment which will be assessed by the revised Experience of Close Relationships Questionnaire (ECR-R 18)(Wongpakaran, 2012)
Interpersonal problems will be assessed by the inventory of interpersonal problems(Horowitz, 2000)
Neuroticism will be assessed by the Neuroticsm Inventory (Wongpakaran,unpublished)

arm_group.description: Participants randomized to this group will receive treatment as usual plus cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) provided by trained Buddhist monks.
Participants randomized into this group will receive treatment as usual (TAU) plus plus routine psychological support from non-CBT monks.

intervention.description: Treatment as usual (TAU)is defined as the routine care provided to each individual patient at the geriatric psychiatry clinic of Maharaj Nakorn Chiang Mai Hospital.
Cognitive behavioral therapy(CBT)includes psychoeducational components combined with cognitive interventions targeted at challenging negative automatic thoughts.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Meet criteria for Major depressive disorder
- receiving antidepressant
Exclusion Criteria:
- presence of intense suicidal intent behaviors that require inpatient admission
- history of alcohol or drug dependence
- presence of hallucinations or delusions
- currently receiving electroconvulsive therapy or repetitive-transcranial magnetic stimulation,
- patients' involvement in other clinical trials.
